I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The recognition that climate change poses serious threats to development and poverty 
reduction efforts is reflected in the country partnership strategies of many Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs). The four pilot countries in the proposed 
technical assistance (TA)—India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand—have emphasized 
the need for stronger integration of climate change into the development process and have 
included climate change adaptation programs, projects, and TA in their respective country 
operations business plans. Lack of information on the magnitude and timing of likely climate 
change impacts has impeded the development of effective climate risk management strategies. 
The TA aims to support the efforts of these countries to better manage climate change risks by 
(i) providing scientifically sound and decision-oriented climate data and projections; and (ii) 
enhancing their technical capacity to generate, interpret, and apply climate information. This will 
enable them to undertake more robust climate risk screening, impact and vulnerability analysis, 
and  assessment  of  potential  adaptation  options.  By  enabling  more  robust  climate  risk 
assessment and management, the TA contributes to safeguarding and sustaining development 
outcomes in Asia and the Pacific under a changing climate. The TA design and monitoring 
framework is Appendix 1.1  
 
2.  Regional  fact-finding  identified  a  consensus  around  the  need  for  detailed  regional 
climate projections, available as public goods, to support climate change adaptation and risk 
management.  The  Environment  and  Safeguards  Division  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development  Department  organized  extensive  consultations  with  representatives  from  the 
world’s leading climate science institutes, regional research centers encompassing many of the 
pilot country implementing agencies, and development partners to scope a regional climate 
projections and data facility and associated approach to developing and delivering the facility.   
  
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The absence of scientifically credible climate change information, and of clear guidelines 
for  its  interpretation  and  use,  have  been  identified  as  strong  impediments  to  the  robust 
assessment of risks related to climate change and to the design and implementation of effective 
adaptation and development projects within Asia and the Pacific. Within the region, which 
contains the highest number of poor people at risk from climate change globally, more readily 
available  and  scientifically  sound  climate  information  is  central  to  improving  the  design  of 
poverty reduction programs in the face of climate change. Improved capacities for developing, 
accessing,  interpreting,  and  applying  climate  change  projections  to  support  climate  risk 
assessments  and  adaptation  planning  are  urgently  needed.  Such  climate  information  and 
supporting products and services are regional public goods and are therefore most effectively 
developed  through  regionally  coordinated  activities.  Regional  climate  data  and  scenarios 
consortia of the type proposed here have been developed for other regions, notably the United 
States and Europe, but not yet for Asia and the Pacific. However, the need for such data and 
scenario  products  within  the  region,  accompanied  by  sound  user  guidance  and  technical 
support, is arguably most compelling because of the high exposure and high vulnerability of 
Asian and Pacific societies to climate-related risks. 
 
4.  To support the integration of climate change considerations into development policies 
and programs in its DMCs, ADB has been investing in developing climate data and projections 
as inputs to climate risk assessments and adaptation planning, often on a project-by-project 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 10 January 2013.

2  
basis. Despite the progress in raising public awareness and quantifying the potential impacts of 
climate change facilitated by these early efforts, there are clearly limitations to the project-based 
approach.  First,  efforts  are  often  constrained  by  the  availability  of  time  and  resources  as 
projects  operate  within  specific  time  frames  and  budget  allocations.  Second,  given  the 
uncertainties  associated  with  climate  projections  and  potential  for  misinterpretation  and 
inappropriate use, the lack of communication between users and developers, as well as the 
absence of practical guidance, undermined the wider and more appropriate use of climate data 
and projections. Third, climate data and projections and associated data sources and underlying 
methodology developed under specific projects are usually not fully documented or archived. 
This makes it difficult for other projects with similar climate information requirements to tap into 
the data and projections from earlier projects. As a result, valuable and limited resources would 
again have to be allocated to develop comparable climate projections for later projects. 
   
5.  Through the establishment of a regional consortium, the proposed TA is designed to 
address these issues and to lay a solid foundation for developing regional public goods and 
services in the form of scientifically robust and decision-oriented climate data and projections in 
a cost-effective fashion. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The primary impact of the TA will be an improved planning process for climate-resilient 
development in selected DMCs under a changing climate. 2 The overall outcome of the TA will 
be an improved climate-resilient program and project design in selected DMCs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
7.  The TA will (i) develop a regional climate projections consortium for the provision of 
robust climate information and supporting services, (ii) develop and deliver decision-oriented 
climate data and projections, and (iii) enhance technical capacity of the implementing agencies 
in the four pilot countries. This is in line with ADB’s catalytic role in (i) leveraging the climate 
science expertise within and beyond Asia and the Pacific, (ii) fostering regional ownership of 
climate  information  and  services,  and  (iii)  strengthening  in-country  technical  capacity.  The 
selection of pilot countries is made on the basis that in these countries (i) there is a clear need 
for improved access to, and technical capacity to develop and use climate data and projections 
to support climate risk assessments and management; (ii) the required levels of expertise and 
infrastructure exist to enable full benefit from the TA support and to ensure the sustainability of 
the consortium beyond the lifetime of the TA; and (iii) there have not been similar initiatives.3  
 
8.  Given the large number of ongoing and planned initiatives in Asia and the Pacific, efforts 
will be made to ensure synergies are explored and duplication of work avoided. 4 In particular, 
                                                 
2  The impact of the TA will not be limited to the participating pilot countries but will extend to other DMCs that will be 
able to access and utilize the climate data and projections facility.  
3  The TA proponent has been systematically reviewing ongoing and planned initiatives in Asia and the Pacific to 
identify synergies, learn from good practices, and avoid duplication of effort. Through extensive discussions and 
consultations with donor agencies and their implementing agencies and centers, the TA team will seek to leverage 
resources and expertise from these initiatives with a view to maximizing the regional benefit from the TA.     
4  These include, among others, ADB-supported TA projects, other multilateral and bilateral supported initiatives such 
as those included in the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience being developed and implemented in selected DMCs 
and the Pacific region.

3
the TA will utilize results, expertise, and experience from ongoing initiatives for the design and 
delivery of project outputs. At the same time, it will add value to these initiatives through the 
establishment of regional mechanisms for technical support and learning.  
 
9.  A wide range of activities are planned to deliver the three outputs, including consultation 
and assessment of needs for climate information and capacity strengthening, targeted climate 
modeling and model performance evaluation, scenario analyses, provision of scenario data 
products and user services, thematic training, communications, and outreach. 
 
10.  Output 1: A regional climate projections consortium for Asia and the Pacific. To 
cost-effectively and sustainably utilize the technical expertise in climate modeling and analysis 
found in leading institutions within and beyond Asia and the Pacific, the consortium presents a 
regional mechanism for developing and applying climate information in support of climate risk 
assessments and management. In contrast to the current practice of engaging climate scientists 
and analysts on an ad-hoc and project-focused basis, the consortium approach will enable 
wider participation and contribution from centers of excellence with relevant expertise, and will 
ensure  that  the  provision  of  technical  advice  and  support  is  institutionalized  and,  hence, 
sustained beyond the lifetime of the TA.5 In addition, the consortium approach will foster a 
greater sense of ownership by regional centers, which in turn will help ensure the long-term 
sustainability of the technical services provided by consortium partners. The consortium will 
comprise centers of excellence with recognized expertise in (i) climate science, (ii) climate risk 
and vulnerability research, (iii) adaptation planning and practice, and (iv) knowledge sharing and 
climate science communications. Partners will be primarily from Asia and the Pacific, but will 
also include international centers of excellence. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Climate  information  products  and  services  for  pilot  countries,  and 
related knowledge products for all developing member countries. These will include the 
following: 
(i)  Scientifically sound, well documented, decision-oriented climate data and 
projections for target countries. Working with consortium partners and based 
on detailed country-level user needs analysis, implementing agencies in the four 
pilot countries will lead the design, development, and dissemination of country-
specific climate information products oriented to user needs.6 These will include 
information  products  to  support  climate-resilient  development  planning  and 
climate risk assessment and management in core economic sectors.   
(ii)  A regional climate data and projections facility. The facility will be the online 
presence of the consortium and a key output of its activities. The facility will 
serve a number of specific functions, including (a) providing general information 
on the TA; (b) facilitating online discussions (ongoing, general, and moderated 
thematic)  around  the  development  and  application  of  climate  information 
products; (c) providing access to climate data and scenario products and other 
associated  knowledge  products  developed  under  the  TA;  (d)  facilitating  the 
                                                 
5  Japan Meteorological Research Institute, Korean Meteorological Administration, Commonwealth Scientific and 
Industrial Research Organisation of Australia, United States National Center for Atmospheric Research, and UK 
Met Office contributed to discussions on the TA concept and expressed strong interest in participating. 
6  Examples of such products include general climate change features such as seasonal changes in core climate 
parameters, changes in the frequency and intensity of extreme events such as droughts and floods, and changes 
in climatic features pertinent to core economic activities and sectors such as changes in reliable rainfall amounts 
(for irrigation management). Changes in climate parameters and related features would be accompanied by 
characterization of uncertainties, e.g., expressed in probabilities and/or likelihoods.

4  
provision of expert advice and services; and (e) providing links to other data, 
scenarios, and knowledge products developed outside the TA. 
(iii)  A “technical template” for developing climate information products that 
are country specific and user needs oriented for other developing member 
countries.  The  technical  processes  involved  in  developing  and  delivering 
climate information products in the four pilot countries (e.g., coordination and 
collaboration mechanisms) will be documented, analyzed, and synthesized into 
a more generic technical template for potential replication in other DMCs. The 
elaboration and dissemination of the template will be informed and supported by 
inputs  from  nonpilot  country  DMCs  through  consultations  and  regional 
knowledge-sharing events.      
 
12.  Output  3:  Enhanced  technical  capacity  for  developing  and  applying  climate 
information products and services in developing member countries. This will have two 
components:  
 (i)  Enhanced technical capacity of implementing agencies in pilot countries 
through learning by doing. Through a combination of working in partnership 
with  international  experts  and  learning  by  doing,  technical  experts  in  pilot 
countries will have the opportunity to enhance their capabilities in a range of 
thematic  areas  associated  with  the  design,  development,  dissemination, 
communication, and application of climate data and projections.   
(ii)  Strengthened technical capacity in pilot countries through development 
and delivery of a series of training courses (modules). Knowledge products 
on the development and application of climate data and scenarios for climate 
risk assessment and adaptation planning, drawn from activities and case studies 
in pilot countries, will be developed and delivered to stakeholders in both pilot 
and nonpilot countries via the data and projections facility as well as "webinar" 
and targeted in-person training sessions.    
 
13.  The TA is built on the premise that improved access to scientifically sound climate data 
and  projections  will  enable  more  robust  climate  risk  assessment,  risk  management,  and 
adaptation decision making. This will in turn improve the effectiveness of poverty reduction and 
development assistance through ensuring the attainment and sustainability of development 
goals in a changing climate. Since the consortium and the facility proposed under the TA will be 
the first of their kind in Asia and the Pacific, a publication will be developed to synthesize good 
practices and lessons learned during the TA for wide dissemination. In addition, a section of the 
internet platform to be developed under the TA will be devoted to sharing and disseminating 
experiences and good practices among users of the platform as an ongoing activity. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,964,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TA, with the Environment and Safeguards 
Division of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department as the focal point. The 
following national climate and meteorology institutions in the TA target countries will be the 
implementing agencies: the Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology in India, the Bureau of

5
Meteorology,  Climatology  and  Geophysics  in  Indonesia,  the  Philippine  Atmospheric 
Geophysical  and  Astronomical  Services  Administration  in  the  Philippines,  and  the  Thai 
Meteorological Department in Thailand. Implementing agencies will play key roles in developing 
and  delivering  climate  data  and  projections  and  technical  capacity  strengthening  in  their 
respective countries, through learning by doing, and close collaboration between implementing 
agency technical staff and experts to be recruited under the TA. Specifically, these agencies will, 
undertake  data  processing  and  analyses  and  provide  support  for  in-country  technical 
coordination, training, and outreach of the TA. Implementing agencies will provide substantial in-
kind contributions, including the time of technical personnel, towards implementation of the TA.      
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 2 years, from April 2013 to March 2015. Initially ADB 
will take the lead in establishing the consortium, defining the scope of and the delivery platform 
for the data facility. Once the consortium is fully functional and the key components of the facility 
are identified, ADB will engage all partners of the consortium to discuss the long-term business 
model  and  will  oversee  a  transition  to  an  operational  mode  conducive  to  self-sustaining 
collaborations among partners. For the initial phase, the ADB officer in charge of this TA will 
supervise and coordinate the activities. Implementation of the substantive TA activities will 
require inputs from a team of six international consultants (57 person-months) and 13 national 
consultants (96 person-months), to be engaged as individuals and to be headed by a team 
leader  who  will  eventually  be  responsible  for  overall  coordination  of  TA  implementation. 
Individual consultants (as opposed to a firm) will be selected because the TA requires a wide 
range of expertise as well as flexibility in their engagement with pilot countries and partners of 
the consortium. Experience from similar initiatives suggests that selecting individual consultants 
increases the likelihood that the diverse expertise required for TA activities will be secured, and 
will provide the flexibility needed to ensure efficient implementation. Terms of reference for 
consultants are provided in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance 
with  the  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Procurement under the TA will be in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time). All disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).7 
No activities will be undertaken in a participating country until the requisite no-objection letters 
have been obtained. 
 
17.   ADB,  as  the  executing  agency,  will  coordinate  periodic  reviews,  both  internal  and 
external,  to  assess  progress, identify  areas for  improvement  in  implementation,  and  make 
required  corrective  changes.  These  reviews  will  assess  not  only  the  outputs  but  also  the 
process of engaging the consortium partners and all stakeholders, particularly those directly 
involved in providing and applying climate data and projections to be developed under the TA 
and beyond.  
 
IV.  THE RANKING VICE-PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
18.  The  Ranking  Vice-President,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions of Article 35.1 of the Articles of Agreement of ADB, recommends that the Board 
approve ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,964,000 to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for a Regional Climate 
Projections Consortium and Data Facility in Asia and the Pacific.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Team Leader (international, 12 person-months) 
 
1.   The team leader will coordinate the activities of the technical assistance (TA), ensure the 
timely delivery of outputs, and provide advice on technical aspects of the TA, including 
(i)  elaboration of final deliverables of the different TA components, including the 
consortium, data, and scenario products and services; capacity building both in 
pilot countries and at the regional level, based on a comprehensive end-user 
assessment; 
(ii)  definition of scope functions, and operational mode of the consortium, taking into 
account comparative advantages of potential partners; 
(iii)  development and selection of a methodological framework for the analyses and 
construction  of  regional  and  national  climate  scenarios,  integrating  emerging 
advances in climate science and regional climate modeling and analyses; 
(iv)  linkage with relevant regional and international initiatives; 
(v)  development and delivery of knowledge products and services; and 
(vi)  the process and steps required to ensure coherence of activities carried out and 
outputs delivered by consortium partners    
 
2.   The team leader is expected to have the following qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at doctorate level, in climate science 
or related field; 
(ii)  10  years  of  working  experience  in  climate  change  impacts,  adaptation  and 
vulnerability, and climate scenario development and application; and 
(iii)  extensive experience in working with developing country adaptation stakeholders 
(including research community, decision makers, and other practitioners). 
 
B.  Senior Climate Scientist (international, 12 person-months) 
 
3.  The senior climate scientist is expected to provide substantive inputs to and guide the 
following aspects of the TA: 
(i)  acquisition of climate model outputs; 
(ii)  evaluation of climate model performances; 
(iii)  updates  on  new  model  outputs  and  their  performance,  and  implications  for 
existing projection products; 
(iv)  development  and  delivery  of  training  and  capacity  building  program  and 
module(s)  including  on  climate  science,  climate  modeling,  climate  model 
evaluation, and uncertainty analyses; and 
(v)  development of knowledge and skills of national climate modeling scientists in 
climate modeling in general and climate model evaluation in particular.     
 
4.  The  senior  climate  scientist  is  expected  to  have  the  following  qualifications  and 
experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at doctorate level, in climate science 
or related field; 
(ii)  10 years of experience in climate modeling and research; 
(iii)  experience of working with research and policy users of climate information; and 
(iv)  experience in developing and delivering training and capacity building.

Appendix 3  11 
C.  Senior Climate Scientists (national,1 32 person-months) 
 
5.  The national senior climate scientists are expected to lead the following activities: 
(i)  development of an inventory of model outputs and observed climate data that 
could be used to develop national climate projections; 
(ii)  evaluation  of  model  performances  for  the  geographic  area  relevant  to  the 
country; 
(iii)  sourcing of observed climate data; 
(iv)  support of the international senior climate scientist in the design, development, 
and delivery of a training and capacity building program and module(s) including 
on climate science, climate modeling, climate model evaluation, and uncertainty 
analyses; and 
(v)  development of skills and expertise in climate modeling and analysis for in-
country climate scientists.       
 
6.  The national senior climate scientists are expected to be citizens of the respective pilot 
countries and have the following qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at doctorate level, in climate science 
or other related fields; 
(ii)  10 years of experience in climate modeling and research; and 
(iii)  experience of working with research and policy users of climate information. 
 
D.  Climate  Change  Impacts,  Adaptation,  and  Vulnerability  Assessment  Specialist 
(international, 12 person-months) 
 
7.  The  specialist  will  provide  technical  guidance  on  and  substantive  inputs  to  the 
development and conduct of 
(i)  a synthesis of user needs and the appropriate scope and format of climate data 
and projection products, and user services; 
(ii)  a  technical  approach  for  developing  user-friendly  and  well-documented  and 
supported climate data, and projection products; 
(iii)  user-friendly and well-documented climate data and projection products for the 
four target countries, based on the technical approach developed in (ii) and using 
the outputs from the most up-to-date climate model experiments; 
(iv)  an  evaluation  of  the  utility  and  effectiveness  of  climate  data  and  projection 
products, and user services; 
(v)  documentation and other publications of good practices and lessons learned on 
using climate data and projections to support adaptation decisions; and 
(vi)  a training and capacity development program and module(s) including on climate 
scenario  analyses;  and  impacts,  adaptation,  and  vulnerability  (IAV) 
methodological frameworks and the application of climate scenarios and decision 
making under uncertainties. 
 
 
8.  The  international  climate  change  IAV  specialist  is  expected  to  have  the  following 
qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree in applied climate science or other related field; 
(ii)  10 years of experience in applied climate research, climate change adaptation, 
and development;

country. 
.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iii)  experience  working  with  climate  modelers  and  adaptation  and  development 
policy makers and practitioners; and 
(iv)  experience developing and delivering training and capacity building. 
      
E.  Climate Change Impacts, Adaptation, and Vulnerability Assessment Specialists 
(national,2 32 person-months) 
 
9.  The national IAV specialists are expected  to lead the following activities: 
(i)  elicit and compile information on user needs, the appropriate scope and format 
for  climate  data  and  scenarios  conducive  to  applications  in  climate  risk 
assessment and adaptation planning;  
(ii)  develop a synthesis of user needs and the appropriate scope and format of 
climate data and projection products, and user services; 
(iii)  develop a technical approach to develop climate data and projection products, 
taking into account user needs and the availability of climate observational data 
within the country; 
(iv)  develop  climate  data  and  scenario  products,  and  associated  technical 
documentation, based on the technical approach developed in (iii) and specific 
user needs as compiled in (ii); 
(v)  collate  information  and  case  studies  relating  to  good  practices  and  lessons 
learned  in  using  climate  information  for  risk  assessments  and  adaptation 
planning; and 
(vi)  support the international IAV specialist in the design and development of an in-
country training and capacity building program and module(s). 
 
10.  The national climate change IAV specialists are expected to be citizens of the respective 
pilot countries and have the following qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at doctorate level, in applied climate 
science, geography, or other related field; 
(ii)  10 years of experience in applied climate research, climate change adaptation, 
and development; and 
(iii)  experience of working with climate modelers and adaptation and development 
policy makers and practitioners. 
 
F.  Knowledge Management Specialist (international, 12 person-months) 
 
11.  The  specialist  will  provide  guidance  on  and  substantive  inputs  to  the  following 
knowledge management activities under the TA: 
(i)  in consultation with the TA management team and the senior climate scientists 
and climate change IAV specialists recruited under the TA, develop a knowledge 
management and outreach strategy for the TA, including the design, planning, 
development, and delivery of knowledge products and events; 
(ii)  coordinate the development and dissemination of knowledge products; 
(iii)  coordinate knowledge events; and 
(iv)  guide  and  coordinate  the  work  of  the  national  knowledge  management 
specialists in target countries.   
 
                                                 
2  One climate change IAV specialist will be recruited for each pilot country and will carry out tasks in the respective 
country. 
.

Appendix 3  13 
12.  The international knowledge management specialist is expected to have the following 
qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at master’s level, in climate science, 
geography, development, science communications, or other related field; 
(ii)  8 years of experience in knowledge management or science communications; 
(iii)  knowledge of climate science, impacts of climate change, development, and 
poverty reduction; and 
(iv)  expertise in or exposure to management information systems.  
 
G.  Knowledge Management Specialists (national,3 24 person-months) 
 
13.  The national knowledge management specialists will lead and coordinate the following 
knowledge management activities within their respective countries:  
(i)  in consultation with the TA management team and the senior climate scientist 
and climate change IAV specialist recruited under the TA, develop a knowledge 
management and outreach strategy with deliverables and timeline for the target 
country, including the design, planning, development, and delivery of knowledge 
products and events;  
(ii)  coordinate the development and dissemination of knowledge products; 
(iii)  coordinate knowledge events; and 
(iv)  provide  inputs  and  technical  assistance  to  national  training  and  capacity 
development activities. 
 
14.  The national knowledge management specialists are expected to be citizens of the 
respective pilot country and have the following qualifications and experience:  
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at master’s level, in climate science, 
geography, development, science communications, or other related field; 
(ii)  5 years of experience in knowledge management or science communications; 
(iii)  knowledge of climate science, impacts of climate change, development, and 
poverty reduction; and 
(iv)  expertise in or exposure to management information systems. 
 
H.  Information Technology Specialist (international, 8 person-months) 
 
15.  The  information  technology  (IT)  specialist  will  lead  the  development,  delivery,  and 
management of the online portal for the regional climate facility. Specific tasks include 
(i)  developing a concept note outlining the overall design, functionality, and data 
management approach for the portal; 
(ii)  developing a beta version of the portal; 
(iii)  organizing the beta testing of the draft portal; 
(iv)  revising the portal, incorporating comments and feedback from beta testing; and 
(v)  carrying out revisions and/or updates to the structure and/or content of the portal 
upon request. 
  
16.  The IT specialist is expected to have the following qualifications and experience: 
(i)  an advanced university degree, preferably at master’s level, in computer science 
or a related field; 
(ii)  8 years of experience developing web-based knowledge platforms;

respective country.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iii)  demonstrable skills in designing user-friendly and computationally efficient web 
portals; and 
(iv)  a basic understanding of key issues relating to climate science, climate change 
impacts, development, and poverty reduction. 
 
I.  Intellectual Property Specialist (international, 1 person-month) 
 
17.  The intellectual property specialist will be responsible for developing intellectual property 
policy with relation to sharing and accessing data, information, and knowledge products under 
the TA. Specific tasks include  
(i)  reviewing existing intellectual property policies and arrangements with relation to 
data and knowledge sharing; 
(ii)  developing a draft intellectual property policy document for data and knowledge 
sharing  under  the  TA  in  consultation  with  international  and  national  climate 
change scientists recruited under the TA; 
(iii)  coordinating the review of the draft intellectual property policy document by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) Office of the General Counsel and stakeholders 
in pilot countries; and 
(iv)  revising and finalizing the intellectual property policy document, incorporating 
comments and inputs from the review. 
 
18.  The intellectual property specialist is expected to have the following qualifications and 
experience: 
(i)  a university degree in intellectual property law; 
(ii)  substantial  international  project  experience,  including  in  Asia  and  intellectual 
property  issues  with  relation  to  access  and  sharing  of  data  collected  and 
maintained  by  governmental  entities,  and  value-added  knowledge  products 
developed by a diverse range of entities; 
(iii)  demonstrable  intellectual  property  experience  in  development,  finance,  and 
nongovernment organization sectors; and 
(iv)  a strong intellectual property network including professional associations across 
Asia and the Pacific. 
 
J.  National Administration Specialist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
19.  A  national  TA  administration  specialist,  to  be  based  in  ADB  headquarters,  will  be 
recruited to undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  carry out necessary administrative tasks to ensure timely implementation of TA 
activities and coordination within ADB and externally; 
(ii)  support the preparation and organization of workshops; 
(iii)  provide support as necessary to the consultant team, and act as liaison between 
the  consultants,  government,  Environment  and  Safeguards  Division, 
implementing agencies, and regional departments; and 
(iv)  provide support as required to ensure smooth implementation of TA activities. 
 
20.  The national administration specialist is expected to have the following qualifications and 
experience: 
(i)  a university degree; 
(ii)  3–5 years experience in a private or public organization prior to joining ADB; and 
(iii)  effective written and oral communication skills in English.
